prompt:
Let
$$f(x)=\frac{x^2-9}{x-3}$$
for $x\ne 3$. Which value of $f(3)$ makes $f$ continuous at $x=3$?
latex:
Let
$$f(x)=\frac{x^2-9}{x-3}$$
for $x\ne 3$. Which value of $f(3)$ makes $f$ continuous at $x=3$?

options.explanation: This equals $x$ at $x=3$, but the simplified expression is $x+3$, not $x$.
Setting $f(3)=0$ does not match the limiting value of $f(x)$ as $x\to 3$.
Since $\frac{x^2-9}{x-3}=x+3$ for $x\ne 3$, the limit as $x\to 3$ is $6$.

options.text: Does not exist (cannot be made continuous)
options.explanation: A removable discontinuity at $x=3$ can be removed by defining $f(3)$ to equal the limit.

explanation: Factor $x^2-9=(x-3)(x+3)$. For $x\ne 3$, $f(x)=x+3$. Therefore $\lim_{x\to 3} f(x)=3+3=6$. Define $f(3)=6$ to make $f$ continuous at $x=3$.

micro_explanations.B: Chooses an arbitrary fill-in value instead of matching the limit.
micro_explanations.C: Matches $f(3)$ to the limit at the hole.
micro_explanations.D: Misclassifies a removable discontinuity as non-removable.

recommendation_reasons: Targets removing a removable discontinuity by redefining a point value.
Reinforces safe canceling with domain awareness.
title: C13-Q1 Fill the Hole by Defining f(3)

prompt:
Define
$$g(x)=\begin{cases}
\frac{x^2-1}{x-1}, & x\ne 1 \\
 k, & x=1
\end{cases}$$
Which value of $k$ makes $g$ continuous at $x=1$?
latex:
Define
$$g(x)=\begin{cases}
\frac{x^2-1}{x-1}, & x\ne 1 \\
 k, & x=1
\end{cases}$$
Which value of $k$ makes $g$ continuous at $x=1$?

options.explanation: The limit as $x\to 1$ is not $0$.
For $x\ne 1$, $\frac{x^2-1}{x-1}=x+1$, so the limiting value at $x=1$ is $2$.
This equals the point $x=1$, but continuity requires matching the function value to the limit.
The discontinuity is removable, so a suitable $k$ exists.

explanation: Factor $x^2-1=(x-1)(x+1)$. For $x\ne 1$, $g(x)=x+1$. Thus $\lim_{x\to 1} g(x)=2$. Continuity at $x=1$ requires $k=2$.

micro_explanations.A: Common when substituting $x=1$ into the numerator only.
micro_explanations.B: Correctly uses the simplified form and matches $k$ to the limit.
micro_explanations.C: Confuses the input value with the function value needed for continuity.
micro_explanations.D: Treats a removable discontinuity as non-removable.

recommendation_reasons: Builds the continuity condition $\lim g(x)=g(1)$ in piecewise form.
Practice factoring and canceling to evaluate limits at holes.
title: C13-Q2 Choose k for Continuity at x=1

options.explanation: This results from incorrectly canceling or substituting without factoring.
This is the value of $x+3$ at $x=-2$, but the simplified expression is $x+3$, giving $1$ only if factoring is done correctly—check carefully.
Sign error after factoring and canceling.
Factor $x^2+5x+6=(x+2)(x+3)$. For $x\ne -2$, the expression is $x+3$, so the limit is $1$.

micro_explanations.A: Often from plugging $x=-2$ too early or canceling incorrectly.
micro_explanations.B: Correct numeric value but paired with an incorrect justification path if not factoring first.
micro_explanations.C: Arises from distributing a negative incorrectly.

recommendation_reasons: Reinforces factoring to remove removable discontinuities.
Targets correct sequencing: simplify first, then substitute.
title: C13-Q3 Limit at a Removable Discontinuity

prompt:
Let
$$h(x)=\begin{cases}
\frac{x^2-4}{x-2}, & x<2 \\
 ax+b, & x\ge 2
\end{cases}$$
If $h$ is continuous at $x=2$ and $h(3)=7$, what are $a$ and $b$?
latex:
Let
$$h(x)=\begin{cases}
\frac{x^2-4}{x-2}, & x<2 \\
 ax+b, & x\ge 2
\end{cases}$$
If $h$ is continuous at $x=2$ and $h(3)=7$, what are $a$ and $b$?

options.explanation: This satisfies continuity at $x=2$ but does not satisfy $h(3)=7$.
Continuity at $x=2$ requires $2a+b=4$, and $h(3)=7$ requires $3a+b=7$; solving gives $a=3$, $b=-2$.
This makes $h(3)=6$, not $7$.
This makes $h(3)=4$, not $7$.

explanation: For $x<2$, $\frac{x^2-4}{x-2}=x+2$ (for $x\ne 2$), so $\lim_{x\to 2^-}h(x)=4$. Continuity at $x=2$ (using the $x\ge2$ branch) gives $h(2)=2a+b=4$. Also $h(3)=3a+b=7$. Subtract: $(3a+b)-(2a+b)=7-4\Rightarrow a=3$. Then $2(3)+b=4\Rightarrow b=-2$.

micro_explanations.B: Correctly sets up two linear equations from continuity and the given value.
micro_explanations.C: Solves only one condition or makes an arithmetic slip.
micro_explanations.D: Treats the right branch as constant due to misreading.

recommendation_reasons: Integrates removable-discontinuity limit with piecewise continuity constraints.
AP-style parameter solve with two conditions.
title: C13-Q4 Continuity + Point Value Determines Line

options.explanation: Rationalize: multiply by the conjugate, then simplify to get a constant limit of $\frac{3}{2}$.
This forgets the factor of $\sqrt{1+3x}+1$ in the denominator after rationalizing.
This comes from substituting $x=0$ directly into an indeterminate form.
The limit exists after algebraic manipulation (rationalization).

micro_explanations.A: Correct conjugate method and substitution after simplification.
micro_explanations.B: Drops the denominator factor created by rationalizing.
micro_explanations.C: Stops at $0/0$ and incorrectly evaluates it as $0$.

recommendation_reasons: Classic ‘remove indeterminate form’ task aligned with removing a discontinuity via algebra.
Strengthens conjugate technique used frequently on AP.
title: C13-Q5 Conjugate to Evaluate a Limit

options.explanation: As $x\to 2^+$, $x-2$ is a small positive number, so the quotient grows without bound.
This would occur for $x\to 2^-$, where $x-2$ is negative.
This misreads a vertical-asymptote limit as a horizontal behavior.
Direct substitution is not valid because the expression is undefined at $x=2$.

micro_explanations.D: Mistakes undefined at the point as a reason the limit cannot be infinite.

recommendation_reasons: Builds correct sign reasoning for one-sided infinite limits.
Directly connects to identifying vertical asymptotes.
title: C14-Q1 One-Sided Infinite Limit of Reciprocal

options.explanation: One factor of $(x-1)$ cancels, but one remains in the denominator, so it is not removable.
As $x\to 1$, the remaining $(x-1)$ in the denominator forces unbounded behavior.
Simplify to $p(x)=\frac{x+2}{x-1}$. As $x\to 1^+$, numerator $\to 3>0$ and denominator $\to 0^+$, so the limit is $+\infty$.
At $x=-2$, the numerator is $0$ (not the denominator), so it is an $x$-intercept, not an asymptote.

explanation: Cancel one $(x-1)$ to get $p(x)=\frac{x+2}{x-1}$ for $x\ne 1$. Since the denominator still goes to $0$ at $x=1$, there is a vertical asymptote at $x=1$. For $x\to 1^+$, $x-1\to 0^+$ and $x+2\to 3$, so $p(x)\to +\infty$.

micro_explanations.A: Cancels too aggressively and forgets the leftover denominator factor.
micro_explanations.C: Correctly distinguishes vertical asymptote vs hole and uses one-sided sign.
micro_explanations.D: Confuses zero of numerator with vertical asymptote.

recommendation_reasons: Targets the high-frequency confusion: hole vs vertical asymptote after partial cancellation.
Reinforces one-sided sign analysis for $\pm\infty$.
title: C14-Q2 Hole vs Vertical Asymptote After Cancellation

options.explanation: For $x\to -3^-$, $(x+3)$ is negative, and an odd power keeps it negative, so the quotient is negative unbounded, not positive.
Unbounded behavior near a vertical asymptote is not $0$.
The limit exists as an infinite limit ($-\infty$).

explanation: When $x\to -3^-$, $x+3\to 0^-$ (small negative). Since the power is odd, $(x+3)^3\to 0^-$. Therefore $\frac{2}{(x+3)^3}\to -\infty$.

micro_explanations.A: Loses the sign behavior for odd powers.
micro_explanations.B: Correctly sign chart near a vertical asymptote with an odd power.
micro_explanations.C: Confuses vertical-asymptote behavior with end behavior.

recommendation_reasons: Strengthens sign reasoning with odd/even powers in denominators.
AP-common trap: left-hand vs right-hand infinite limits.
title: C14-Q3 Odd Power Denominator Sign to -Infinity

prompt:
For
$$q(x)=\frac{x^2-4x+3}{x^2-5x+6},$$
which $x$-value is a vertical asymptote of $q$?
latex:
For
$$q(x)=\frac{x^2-4x+3}{x^2-5x+6},$$
which $x$-value is a vertical asymptote of $q$?

options.explanation: A factor of $(x-2)$ cancels, creating a hole (removable discontinuity), not a vertical asymptote.
After cancellation, $(x-3)$ remains in the denominator, so $x=3$ is a vertical asymptote.
$x=1$ is a zero of the numerator, not a zero of the (uncanceled) denominator.
There is a vertical asymptote at the uncanceled denominator zero.

explanation:
Factor:
$$x^2-4x+3=(x-1)(x-3),\qquad x^2-5x+6=(x-2)(x-3).$$
Then
$$q(x)=\frac{(x-1)(x-3)}{(x-2)(x-3)}=\frac{x-1}{x-2}$$
for $x\ne 3$. The factor $(x-3)$ cancels, so $x=3$ is a hole. The remaining denominator zero is $x=2$, which is the vertical asymptote of the simplified function; however $x=2$ was never canceled, so it is the vertical asymptote of $q$.

Therefore the vertical asymptote is at $x=2$? Wait: after simplification the denominator is $(x-2)$, so the vertical asymptote is $x=2$.

micro_explanations.A: Correctly identifies the simplified denominator but may be chosen for the wrong reason if cancellation is misunderstood.
micro_explanations.B: Confuses the canceled factor (hole) with a vertical asymptote.

recommendation_reasons: Targets distinguishing holes from vertical asymptotes via factoring and cancellation.
Reinforces that vertical asymptotes come from uncanceled denominator zeros.
title: C14-Q4 Identify Vertical Asymptote vs Hole by Factoring

options.explanation: Because $(x-4)^2\ge 0$ on both sides of $4$, the expression cannot go to $-\infty$ if the numerator is positive near $4$.
Near $x=4$, $x+1\to 5>0$ and $(x-4)^2\to 0^+$, so the quotient grows to $+\infty$ from both sides.
An infinite limit is a valid limit behavior; it does not automatically mean DNE here.
Direct substitution fails because the denominator becomes $0$.

explanation: As $x\to 4$, the numerator $x+1\to 5$ (positive). The denominator $(x-4)^2\to 0^+$ from both sides because of the square. Therefore the expression approaches $+\infty$.

micro_explanations.A: Forgets that a squared denominator stays nonnegative.
micro_explanations.B: Correctly uses positivity of numerator and $0^+$ denominator.
micro_explanations.C: Treats infinite limit as invalid rather than as $+\infty$.
micro_explanations.D: Misapplies direct substitution despite division by zero.

recommendation_reasons: Highlights that even powers yield the same sign on both sides (both sides to $+\infty$).
Connects infinite limits to vertical asymptote behavior.
title: C14-Q5 Even Power Denominator Gives +Infinity Both Sides
